Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Semi-Active Controlled Cladding Panels for Multi-Hazard Resilient Buildings

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Building facades typically consist of cladding that is placed on the outside perimeter of the structure. Traditionally, cladding serves purposes of providing architectural envelope and protection to the occupants from the outside elements. The goal of this research project is to rethink cladding systems as multi-functional structural units. Not only would the cladding serve its traditional purposes, but it would also be engaged as an engineered system to protect the structure against multiple hazards, including seismic, wind, and blast loads. Cladding serves both as the point of application of externally applied lateral loads such as wind and blast as well as a contributor of added inertia to seismic or wind-induced vibrations. This project will explore the use of semi-active controlled connections between cladding and the structural framing of a building - these connections will be capable of providing variable damping to mitigate the effects of extreme loading. The results of the project will engage the cladding on a building to enhance a structure's resilience to multiple hazards. The professions of architecture and structural engineering will need to collaborate in design of cladding in the future.

The focus of this project is to develop computational simulation of a prototype semi-active damping device, installed between the cladding and structural frame, to the varying loading frequencies and intensities from multiple hazards. The objective of the system is twofold: (1) to engage the cladding as a mass damper to mitigate inter-story drift due to lateral load vibrations; and (2) to utilize the device as an energy dissipator under lateral loads. An innovative semi-active device with decentralized control laws will be developed to satisfy the varying energy dissipation and control objectives associated with each hazard. The research team will perform advanced nonlinear numerical simulations of realistic buildings with semi-active damping devices to assess the various parameters that influence the control laws and performance of the devices. The simulations will be validated through large-scale experiments in the laboratory. The experiments will include real-time hybrid simulations for wind and seismic loading that account for the complete building system and its interactions with the semi-active damping devices and cladding. Air-blast shock tube tests will be conducted to simulate blast loading. Performance-based design procedures will be established to integrate the design of semi-active cladding within a holistic structural design approach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project investigated a new concept that integrates the design of a building’s cladding system, which is typically viewed as non-structural, into the design of the building’s structural system. The project generated and studied a semi-active damping device, termed variable friction cladding connection, engineered to be installed at the lateral connections between the cladding and structural system of a building, for mitigating vibrations induced by different hazards including seismic, wind, and blast. The damping force of the device can be modulated using an actuated toggle system that varies the normal force applied onto the friction plates (see figure). The project produced: 1) a prototype of the device tested in a laboratory environment; 2) a dynamic model characterizing the behavior of the device; 3) a design procedure to holistically integrate the device within the structural system for seismic, wind, and blast mitigation; 4) data supporting the efficacy of the device against seismic, wind, and blast loads; and 5) a numerical demonstration of the device at mitigating non-simultaneous multiple hazards.

 Research outcomes listed above generated tools, procedures, and data supporting the implementation of the variable friction cladding connection within structural systems. Some of these results can be generalized to other semi-active devices, therefore broadening the acceptability of such high performance damping devices for reducing vibrations in civil systems, in particular against multiple hazards.  Close interactions with the industry during the project, including Taylor Devices and Eastern Exterior Wall Systems, have contributed to generating realistic outcomes empowering faster technology transition in the field. The broad implementation of these devices will significantly improve structural safety, resiliency, and sustainability, while reducing costs associated with the construction of structural systems. The project trained two Ph.D students, two M.Sc students, and three REU students, and five undergraduate students were involved with the research. Results have been disseminated in 11 juried journal/conference papers, at four conferences, and presented in an undergraduate and a graduate course over a fully dedicated lecture on challenges in structural resiliency. A small group of undergraduate students participated in a research project that consisted of creating vibration reduction devices using 3D printing.
